@celinegounder ...saying, "You couldn't be allergic to Sulfa.  No one's allergic to Sulfa anymore."  And that was how I learned how much Benadryl my body could tolerate.

My regular doctor let me sit in his office and put the call on speaker phone when he reamed that doc out.

@celinegounder ..."Oh my system flagged that, but it hardly ever happens so just go ahead and take it."

@celinegounder A physician once gave me a new prescription, and when I got to the pharmacy, the pharmacist said, "this doesn't work with your Sulfa allergy."

I reached out to my doctor and let them know, to which they replied...

text: So the place (a dentist)  where I went to get a covid test prior to visiting my dad in hospital had a commendable policy of changing the password daily. Instructions on how to do it were helpfully taped to the computer. Superb information security https://t.co/IyEP4tBiiO
comments: @ScornflakeGrrrl That's one way to do it I guess! 🤣

@basilbrushoff Tbh I reset my password every time I need to access something because I can never remember them. That together with tfa feels fairly safe. Biggest thread is still phishing/social engineering
@JV8P Awesome. Also loving these password books that Amazon sells https://t.co/QVrG8pz81r

@ScornflakeGrrrl Yeah, true. Context is everything. Also I agree with the other commenter that a fixed strong password is better than a series of weaker ones. I tweak it based on use case but I think my password generator for online use is about 15 characters, A-Z/a-z/0-9/symbols.

@ScornflakeGrrrl A contact at HMRC once had to visit a high street accountancy practice whose login credentials had been compromised to discuss the incident/offer guidance.
The password was on a whiteboard which was visible through a window from the (busy) pavement as he approached the building.
@basilbrushoff If it was in a room where strangers wouldn’t be left alone in to be seen I agree with you. But I have been audited for 27001 so much I tend to twitch quite quickly now

@ScornflakeGrrrl Honestly I don't even hate it. Generally once someone has physical access to a machine (nearly) all bets are off anyway.

Of course I'd like more people/services to use stronger authentication methods like password managers or, better, private key authentication, but... 🤷‍♂️

@ScornflakeGrrrl One day, people will learn that a good password is better than one you have to change every day. I'm 99% certain daily/weekly/monthly passwords either have the date or an increasing number as the only thing that changes

text:
I find the new CDC COVID-19 Community Level metric problematic.

It's clear that cases rates can be very high and CDC will still not call 'Community Levels' High - until hospitalization rates go way up, which could be way too late into surge, IMO. https://t.co/iLCGLpJMZL
comments: @walidgellad You can make your own decisions obviously but these guidelines seem to be tailored to Omicron. You think it should be otherwise?

@walidgellad It's not one's personal risk of getting COVID. It should one's personal risk of getting very sick with COVID. Getting COVID is fine and not worth preventing if you are not going to get very sick with it, and this is what CDC is trying to recognize.
@walidgellad Depends what is transmitting. A high-level of community transmission of a very weak variant that does not send people to hospitals should be green. I am glad CDC recognizes that.

@walidgellad I'm more upset about the long tail, where the situation is much improved, risk is way back down, but hospital numbers (especially in rural areas) are still too high per 100K. https://t.co/sjQ4kACtwh

@KelleyKga agree. It's set up so that a community can mask before all heck  breaks loose and hospitals are out of beds, but not a good measure of when a surge is coming or to determine your own personal risk, if you care about avoiding covid.

@walidgellad I made the same argument. Hospitalizations also stay high well after the situation improves. It feels more like masks are being used as a punishment for having a surge than anything else.  https://t.co/gKyu7RkVy6

@walidgellad The whole country needs to sidestep relying on people and set up wastewater testing in-real time.  It'll be more reliable than a mix of delayed or unavailable pcr lab data and underreporting because people are testing at home or are asymptomatic.

The best measure of how much community transmission there is....is how much community transmission there is. 

That, for me, tells me what I'm going to do to address my particular risk situation. Not whether hospitals are full.

So I won't use it to make my decisions.
@walidgellad Even cases are too late a metric. Should be based on wastewater levels.

Hospitalizations are way too late a metric, especially in a population heavily vaccinated or if surge hits young people first. 

It's fine for thinking about burden on health resources in a community, but I would not use it as a measure of one's personal risk of getting covid.

text:
I find the new CDC COVID-19 Community Level metric problematic.

It's clear that cases rates can be very high and CDC will still not call 'Community Levels' High - until hospitalization rates go way up, which could be way too late into surge, IMO. https://t.co/iLCGLpJMZL
comments: @walidgellad You can make your own decisions obviously but these guidelines seem to be tailored to Omicron. You think it should be otherwise?

@walidgellad It's not one's personal risk of getting COVID. It should one's personal risk of getting very sick with COVID. Getting COVID is fine and not worth preventing if you are not going to get very sick with it, and this is what CDC is trying to recognize.
@walidgellad Depends what is transmitting. A high-level of community transmission of a very weak variant that does not send people to hospitals should be green. I am glad CDC recognizes that.

@walidgellad I'm more upset about the long tail, where the situation is much improved, risk is way back down, but hospital numbers (especially in rural areas) are still too high per 100K. https://t.co/sjQ4kACtwh

@KelleyKga agree. It's set up so that a community can mask before all heck  breaks loose and hospitals are out of beds, but not a good measure of when a surge is coming or to determine your own personal risk, if you care about avoiding covid.

@walidgellad I made the same argument. Hospitalizations also stay high well after the situation improves. It feels more like masks are being used as a punishment for having a surge than anything else.  https://t.co/gKyu7RkVy6

@walidgellad The whole country needs to sidestep relying on people and set up wastewater testing in-real time.  It'll be more reliable than a mix of delayed or unavailable pcr lab data and underreporting because people are testing at home or are asymptomatic.

The best measure of how much community transmission there is....is how much community transmission there is. 

That, for me, tells me what I'm going to do to address my particular risk situation. Not whether hospitals are full.

So I won't use it to make my decisions.
@walidgellad Even cases are too late a metric. Should be based on wastewater levels.

Hospitalizations are way too late a metric, especially in a population heavily vaccinated or if surge hits young people first. 

It's fine for thinking about burden on health resources in a community, but I would not use it as a measure of one's personal risk of getting covid.

text:
1/🧵 Let’s talk Long COVID:

I’m grouping several important & interesting articles about the reality of #LongCOVID.

By studying brain fluid, viral persistence & MRIs, we’re building our understanding of the “how” & “why” of this devastating malady.

A train is coming, read on… https://t.co/dUcsMiWxXB
comments: @MaryLaGuerita @WesElyMD @EIonaSt @glynmoody Your best bet would be to see a neuropsychologist - ideally one who specializes in treating patients with brain injury.
@roxy_mojo @Cherdogmama @WesElyMD @CIBScenter :( that's terrible. People don't realize how debilitating it is because it didn't happen to them. What's yours like?

@constantaspara1 I'm not sure where I haven't addressed your concerns. Low processing speed is very common with autism, it's not totally unrelated. I'm not saying anything bad about autism. I'm sorry you took offense to what was supposed to be an empathetic remark, not my intention.
@WesElyMD Thank you so much for this.

@WesElyMD @forsaken911 You are welcome. I had read somewhere that a woman went into psychosis after Covid, and it made me wonder if my sudden issue was from vaccine. ‘Twas VERY strange! Perfectly fine again, except for lifelong Complex PTSD.
@WesElyMD And let’s not leave behind those with #MECFS who suffer similar issues

@Jellyjamjelly @WesElyMD I understand that your son experiences difficulties related to his processing speed and that you don’t want others to have the same struggles. Are my tweets clear? If not, please let me know so I can clarify. You haven’t addressed my concerns yet.
@constantaspara1 @WesElyMD This was the particular piece I was referencing. "How frustrating would it be in daily life to think that slowly".  Because he lives with it daily. https://t.co/n6XnLQu6vB

@Jellyjamjelly @WesElyMD I appreciate your concern, and like I said, it’s clear that you have good intentions. I can see that you’re concerned about what the future holds for long haulers and I thank you for it.

@Jellyjamjelly @WesElyMD And my point was that your son’s processing speed is not from his autism because the two are unrelated (unless he’s in sensory overload). There was no reason to mention autism at all. When others repeatedly hear that we’re slow, it hurts our employability and worsens the stigma.

text: This is Brady/tachy heart rate from #covid. I am 2 years post infection. I have #longcovid. I’m not posting this for sympathy- there are millions just like me dealing with  this illness. This is a PSA. It’s not over. I was healthy and  youngish. Now this is daily reality. #mask https://t.co/akjm8QsJwN
comments: @roxy_mojo @RJDixon741 Yes!
@LaRougeAbeille @RJDixon741 Is this the one? https://t.co/sxilaUB2NY

@roxy_mojo Right there with you. This looks like the picture of someone doing hard core cardio training. But it’s not. I spent most of that 12 months resting, the crazy spikes happening when I walked to the bathroom. https://t.co/vvRLBv5Pug
@calirunnerdoc Absolutely. I know people must tire of my posts. But people need to see. It’s not feeling sleepy or wanting a rest. It’s chronic multi-system destruction. Thank you.
@roxy_mojo My sedentary heart rate today. I’ve spent most of the day in bed 🤷🏻‍♀️ https://t.co/DqDGrpLJDy

@RJDixon741 @roxy_mojo It’s a Circul ring, that connects via Bluetooth to my partner’s phone. An alarm wakes him up if my sats drop below 90, and it generates a nightly report in the app. It’s expensive, but I need to have proof.
@roxy_mojo Clots are what I imagine as well. A basic chest X-ray won’t be sufficient for that, but they have to get it out of the way. 😔
@LaRougeAbeille I have oxygen and a cpap machine now. There’s not a lot they can really do- but it’s important that we get oxygen support and use meds to stop further fibrosis etc.

@LaRougeAbeille They may be able to do a home sleep study for you. That’s what I did.  I crash hard also. 💔 I have a pulmo appt tomorrow so hopefully we will schedule a VQ scan again to check for clots. Major reason for low sats with long Covid. But we will see. I will update after appt.
@roxy_mojo At this point, just ruling out really obvious stuff. I don’t know if they’ll be willing to look any deeper. Are you getting support for your low sats?

text:
Last night we launched the evaluation of Newham’s Covid 19 Health Champions 

The work has been at the heart of our response to the pandemic, helping us share messages deeply and widely across our communities & and hear from the ground on a daily basis 1/

https://t.co/MRjRGXGn0O https://t.co/WgkXwJqaen
comments: @strelitz_jason @rokhsanafiaz @zulfiqar1107 @AnnePBowers @ProfKevinFenton 👍Incredible work PH Team and Covid Champs⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Some challenges going forward?
- continuing to strive for inclusion of different voices 
- maintaining involvement when challenges are long term rather than the acute crises of pandemic 
- keeping energy & spirit in ways that allow us to manage alongside non work life 4/

The biggest surprises of the work? 
- the new community that formed of people coming together from vary diverse backgrounds with a shared goal of supporting their community
- the many active champions & ways people shared & cascaded information that we never knew about 3/

We learned so much from this work that can help guide us in to the future on how to build a true partnership between public service and our communities rooted in collaboration, openness, respect, responsiveness, everyday technologies and even fun & laughter ! 2/

text: Covid in the UK now. A thread on whats happening. Its... Complicated. And its not good. Here's the increasingly hard to interpret overall picture, and I'll go into the trends in this thread (1) https://t.co/fqvB0eH98H
comments: @gnomeicide Sadly the message that's got through is masks are unnecessary. My elderly parents seem happy to sit unmasked in a theatre with 200 people, go to church or pub, where even the serving staff are unmasked. It's not going to end well.

@gnomeicide I just feel the Ukraine invasion we have had no information at all, nobody is paying attention anymore.  Obviously, the gov have moved on and we are not going to have any restrictions reimbursed. Steve Baker M.P. wouldn't allow it! I continue to mask, vax and hope for the best!

Mass infection may follow soon, in fact looking at  trends its likely happening now. That creates the conditions for more dangerous forms of Covid to arise. We have a problem, ignoring it won't make it go away, its now just a matter of how long it takes us to realise that (fin)

It will not have escaped your attention that we're also in the midst of a fuel price crisis. For all sorts of reasons we need to go back to a working at home if possible mandate. It will save lives, and it will save fuel (20)
So what do we do now? Well I should think its obvious. What we were doing was working reasonably well, but not as well as we'd have hoped. We need masks back. Thats urgent (19)
And I've got to say I don't like where this trend is going - last year we were rightly angry about how many were dying. We're rapidly on course to get to a worse place (18) https://t.co/Q4hlaH3G9C

Deaths are rising as a proportion of infection. Thats either because we're starting to see immunity from vaccination fall, or we're not catching as many infections through testing. (17) https://t.co/xDbiLN4b6T

We've done the same thing with reopening now, but in Winter. The gains we had made, the good direction we were going in (although too slowly), that has ended now. But its in the relationship between these markers that the real problem emerges (16)

Last summer things turned around when we opened up in July. We saw a slow rise in cases that soon led to mass infection that created the Alpha strain of Covid, and a far more rapid acceleration from an already bad place into Autumn (15)
And while deaths lag further behind, deaths follow hospitalisations (14) https://t.co/I3av12xSsz
